elements.content: A series of structurally related rigid imidazole ligands, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L 1 ), 1,4-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)benzene (L 2 ), and 4,4′-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)biphenyl (L 3 ), have been utilized to construct coordination polymers. The reactions of CdX2 (X = BF4 − or ClO4 −) with these ligands afford three new three-dimensional networks, {[Cd(L 1 )3](BF4)2(CHCl3)2}∞ (1), {[Cd(L 2 )3](ClO4)2(CHCl3)4(CH3OH)2}∞ (2), and {[Cd(L 3 )3](ClO4)2}∞ (3). Compounds 1−3 are all α-Po metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) based on six-connected CdII nodes which are octahedrally coordinated by six nitrogen atoms of ligand molecules. Complex 2 represents a distorted α-Po framework with noninterpenetration, whereas 1 and 3 both exhibit a double interpenetrating α-Po network. These results suggest that the degree of interpenetration is tunable by ligand modifications, that is, varying the ligand spacer or terminal group. The three complexes exhibit a different void volume in their network. Gas adsorption measurements indicate that 3 possesses moderate gas-adsorption ability for CO2, and the progress of adsorption and desorption is reversible.

elements.content: Three coordination polymers exhibiting three-dimensional α-Po networks were isolated from the self-assembly of CdX2 (X = ClO4 − or BF4 −) with a series of rigid bis(imidazole) ligands. A comparison of the structure of the three complexes reveals that the porosity and degree of interpenetration is tunable by ligand modification. The adsorption property of complex 3 was briefly studied.

elements.content: The rational design of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted considerable current attention, which is primarily propelled by their many potential applications as diverse as gas storage, catalysis, nonlinear optics, electronics, and enantioselective separations. Among them, porous materials associated with capacity for gas adsorption is of great interest, and the rapid growth in the area of porous MOFs continues to provide many interpenetrating architectures with interesting topologies; however, interpenetration in porous MOFs may greatly reduce the volume of pores. Thus, an investigation of the correlation between the porosity and interpenetration, and tuning the degree of interpenetration of network via modification of ligands is a large concern for synthetic chemists. Besides the span of ligands, factors that affect the void and interpenetration are intricate and diverse in the assembly process, including ligand bulkiness, counterion, size of SBU nodes, and subtle conformation of flexible ligand. So far, some extensive research reports have contributed to elaborating the influencing factors on the porosity and interpenetration, for example, ideal cubic networks, and throwing a bright light on control over the void.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted considerable current attention, which is primarily propelled by their many potential applications as diverse as gas storage, catalysis, nonlinear optics, electronics, and enantioselective separations. Among them, porous materials associated with capacity for gas adsorption is of great interest, and the rapid growth in the area of porous MOFs continues to provide many interpenetrating architectures with interesting topologies; however, interpenetration in porous MOFs may greatly reduce the volume of pores. Thus, an investigation of the correlation between the porosity and interpenetration, and tuning the degree of interpenetration of network via modification of ligands is a large concern for synthetic chemists. Besides the span of ligands, factors that affect the void and interpenetration are intricate and diverse in the assembly process, including ligand bulkiness, counterion, size of SBU nodes, and subtle conformation of flexible ligand. So far, some extensive research reports have contributed to elaborating the influencing factors on the porosity and interpenetration, for example, ideal cubic networks, and throwing a bright light on control over the void.

elements.content: Because of the special metal-coordinating ability of imidazoles, research on imidazole-containing ligands has experienced a drastic development, and a large number of networks have been reported. As a continuation of our previous study, in this contribution, a series of rigid ligands, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L 1 ), 1,4-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)benzene (L 2 ), and 4,4′-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl) biphenyl (L 3 ) (Chart ), have been selected and reacted with CdX2 (X = BF4 − or ClO4 −), and three new coordination frameworks, {[Cd(L 1 )3](BF4)2(CHCl3)2}∞ (1), {[Cd(L 2 )3](ClO4)2(CHCl3)4(CH3OH)2}∞ (2), {[Cd(L 3 )3](ClO4)2}∞ (3), have been obtained and characterized. The relationship between the interpenetrating degree and porosity tuned by ligand backbones is also discussed. Furthermore, the gas adsorption/desorption properties for 3 have been investigated.

Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the solvents and reagents for synthesis were commercially available and used as received. The ligands, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L  1 ) and 1,4-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)benzene (L  2 ), were synthesized according to the reported procedure, and the synthesis of 4,4'-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)biphenyl (L  3 ) was achieved by copper-catalyzed N-arylation of azoles with aryl bromides, with regard to Ullmann-type condensation.

elements.content: Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were measured on a TENSOR 27 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AC-P500 spectrometer (300 MHz) in CDCl3 medium at 25 °C with tetramethylsilane as the internal reference. The mass spectra were recorded on Thermo Finnigan LCQ-Advantage spectrometer in ESI mode, I Spray Voltage 4.8 kV. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV, 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. The thermal stability (TG-DTA) study was carried out on a Rigaku standard TG-DTA analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1. Measurements for the gas adsorption isotherms of CO2 (195 K) of desolvated crystal powder were performed in the gaseous state by using BELSORP-max volumetric adsorption equipment from BEL Japan.

elements.content: A mixture of 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl (12.0 mmol, 3.74 g), benzoimidazole (60.0 mmol, 7.09 g), CuI (2.5 mmol, 0.47 g), 1,10-phenanthroline (6.0 mmol, 1.08 g), and K2CO3 (96.0 mmol, 13.27 g) was suspended in 120 mL of DMF. The mixture was refluxed for 6 days and then cooled to room temperature. Solvent was removed by distillation under a vacuum. CHCl3 (250 mL) was poured into the resulting brown sticky residue. The filtrate was washed with water (200 mL × 3), dried over anhydrous MgSO4, and then evaporated to obtain light-green mud. CAU T ION! Although we have met no problems in handling perchlorate salt during this work, these should be treated cautiously, owing to their potential explosive nature.

X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determinations

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data of 1−3 were collected on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 with graphite monochromatic Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps and other non-hydrogen atoms excluded in counterions were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. The ClO4 − anions in 1 and 3 are disordered. In compound 1, the ClO4 − anion was treated as a trigonal biyramid, whereas the disordered ClO4 − anion of 3 was split into two tetrahedrons. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically. However, the hydrogen atoms of the host methanol molecules in 2 were added by difference Fourier maps. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1−3 are listed in Table .

In this work, three structurally related rigid bis(imidazole) ligands, L 1 , L 2 , and L 3 were employed as building blocks to perform a systematic study to adjust the porosity and degree of interpenetration of their coordination polymers. These ligands have small differences in terminal groups or ligand spacers. As shown in Chart , the terminal groups are swollen from imidazole in L 1 to benzoimidazole in L 2 and the ligand spacers are elongated from phenyl in L 2 to biphenyl in L 3 . The CdII ion was chosen as the metal node, and it usually maintains octahedral coordination geometry.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis Consideration

In this work, three structurally related rigid bis(imidazole) ligands, L  1 , L  2 , and L  3  were employed as building blocks to perform a systematic study to adjust the porosity and degree of interpenetration of their coordination polymers. These ligands have small differences in terminal groups or ligand spacers. As shown in Chart , the terminal groups are swollen from imidazole in L  1  to benzoimidazole in L  2  and the ligand spacers are elongated from phenyl in L  2  to biphenyl in L  3 . The CdII ion was chosen as the metal node, and it usually maintains octahedral coordination geometry.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n. The coordination geometry of CdII is distorted octahedron, surrounded by six imidazole rings of distinct L 1 ligands (Figure a). The length of equatorial bonds are 2.335(5) Å and 2.345(5) Å, with an elongation to 2.400(5) Å for axial bonds, which corresponds to the reported values. Notably, the structural moiety is the “hexa-star”, in which metal center acts as a six-connected node and L 1 ligand acts as a linear bridge. The “hexa-star”, with two 14.305 Å and four 14.02 Å “spokes”, expands into infinite quasi-helices along crystallographic a axis. The screw distance, given by the distance between equivalent atoms generated by one full rotation of the 3-fold screw axis, is 16.594 Å.

Crystal Structure of 1

Notably, the structural moiety is the "hexa-star", in which metal center acts as a six-connected node and L  1  ligand acts as a linear bridge. The "hexa-star", with two 14.305 Å and four 14.02 Å "spokes", expands into infinite quasi-helices along crystallographic a axis. The screw distance, given by the distance between equivalent atoms generated by one full rotation of the 3-fold screw axis, is 16.594 Å.

elements.content: Further analysis reveals that the trigonal aperture is reinforced with another infinite quasi-helix from the second framework. That is, each aperture is surrounded by two synchronous quasi-helices from equivalent frameworks. However, these trigonal apertures are packed in an antiparallel manner with opposite chiralities (Figure b). As exhibited by the infinite double-stranded helix, the most fascinating structural feature of 1 is that the architecture is composed of two equivalent frameworks. Topological analysis suggests that these two independent identical frameworks are interlocked with each other to give a double interpenetrating α-Po network (Figure c). As a consequence, the overall void volume after interpenetration is about 935.6 Å3, that is, 38.7% of the cell volume using the PLATON program. Unfortunately, the void space in the aperture is occupied by BF4 − counteranions and chloroform molecules (Figure d).

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c containing four symmetry-related CdII nodes in each unit cell. As shown in Figure a, the CdII ion lies in an octahedral coordination environment of six N-donors from independent L 2 ligands. These Cd−N bond lengths span a narrow range [2.368(3)−2.388(3) Å] in accord with the reported values. In the octahedral coordination geometry, the phenyl rings of benzoimidazole groups lie on the equatorial plane resulting in a loose arrangement, due to the cooperative effect of steric hindrance and π−π stacking. This array of terminal groups also steers the expanded direction of L 2 ligand, one-half upward, and downward for another (Figure a). The L 2 ligand bridges two adjacent CdII centers, and eight CdII nodes are connected by the ligands to form a cubic box with Cd···Cd separations of 13.032 and 13.973 Å (Figure b). A further extended structure illustrates a primitive cubic array without interpenetration. Significantly, the Cd···Cd edge of 13.973 Å is crisscross and spreads in two directions, which displays a distorted α-Po topology (Figure c). Because of its long dimensional edges, the cubic box shows much vacant space, and the overall void volume is about 3380.5 Å3, that is, 45.2% of the cell volume; however, the void space within this cationic framework {[Cd(L 2 )3]2+}∞, namely, the Mitsubishi channels, is occupied by ClO4 − counterions, chloroform and methanol molecules (Figure d).

elements.content: Different from 1 and 2, compound 3 crystallizes rhombohedrally with a high-symmetry space group R32, where the CdII ion maintains CdN6 coordination geometry. As shown in Figure a, the metal center and anion center both sit on the crystallographic C 3 axis, and the CdII ion is octahedrally coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from six individual L 3 ligands. The corresponding bond lengths and angles show a slight difference from those of 2 (Table ). Each CdII center is bridged to six adjacent metal centers through L 3 ligands to form an α-Po network, with an intraframework Cd···Cd distance 17.818 Å. Because of the long spacer in this compound, the void in lattice is large enough to accommodate another equivalent network, allowing mutual interpenetration of two equivalent frameworks related by C 2 symmetry (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 3 

Different from 1 and 2, compound 3 crystallizes rhombohedrally with a high-symmetry space group R32, where the CdII ion maintains CdN6 coordination geometry. As shown in Figure a, the metal center and anion center both sit on the crystallographic C 3 axis, and the CdII ion is octahedrally coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from six individual L  3  ligands. The corresponding bond lengths and angles show a slight difference from those of 2 (Table ). Each CdII center is bridged to six adjacent metal centers through L  3  ligands to form an α-Po network, with an intraframework Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance 17.818 Å. Because of the long spacer in this compound, the void in lattice is large enough to accommodate another equivalent network, allowing mutual interpenetration of two equivalent frameworks related by C 2 symmetry (Figure b).

elements.content: Furthermore, the aperture is composed of two single-stranded helices from two equivalent frameworks, and shows infinite double helical structure (Figure a). The screw distance, given by the distance between equivalent atoms generated by one full rotation of the 3-fold screw axis, is 38.274 Å. Further analysis shows that there are no obvious hydrogen-bonding and π−π stacking interactions between the two helices, and they are connected through intermolecular or van der Waals interactions. Two helices are of the same handedness and intertwined to form a one-dimensional (1D) chiral channel (Figure b). Furthermore, these channels are packed in a parallel manner with the same chirality in one piece of crystal. The CdII node of one framework lies at the body center of the other, resulting in the shortest interframework Cd···Cd distance of 13.979 Å, which results in a 1D trigonal channel along the c axis (Figure b). Significantly, there are no solvent molecules residing in this aperture, representing a rare guest-free MOF material. The overall void volume is about 4034.3 Å3, that is, 52.4% of the cell volume (Figure c). As ClO4 − anions and CdII ions reside in the C 3 axis, the vacancy of this aperture is more available, which indicates that compound 3 is a good example of interpenetrating MOFs that show large pores.

elements.content: All the structures of compounds 1−3 show α-Po topology, which facilitates us to investigate the correlation of degree of interpenetration with ligand backbone. Quantum calculation shows that the volume of coordination sphere comprising one CdII center and six imidazole rings is 334.6 cm3/mol in 1, whereas the volume of the CdII node consisting of one CdII center and six benzoimidazole molecules is 523.0 cm3/mol for 2. Therefore, bulky terminal groups usually result in a larger coordination sphere, and further bear a negative effect on the degree of interpenetration.
elements.clean_text:
Tunable Interpenetrating Degrees and Porosity

All the structures of compounds 1-3 show α-Po topology, which facilitates us to investigate the correlation of degree of interpenetration with ligand backbone. Quantum calculation shows that the volume of coordination sphere comprising one CdII center and six imidazole rings is 334.6 cm3/mol in 1, whereas the volume of the CdII node consisting of one CdII center and six benzoimidazole molecules is 523.0 cm3/mol for 2. Therefore, bulky terminal groups usually result in a larger coordination sphere, and further bear a negative effect on the degree of interpenetration.

elements.content: As shown in Chart , in 1, the space linker is phenyl group, which could result in a moderate cavity in the targeted architecture. Taking the 334.6 cm3/mol coordination sphere into account, the α-Po network can accommodate another equivalent network to afford 2-fold interpenetration, which gives rise to 935.6 Å3 void after interpenetration, that is, 38.7% of the cell volume. For 2, although the space linker is the same as that of 1, the terminal group is much more bulky, and the volume of coordination sphere is up to 523.0 cm3/mol. The pronounced effect results in a noninterpenetrating network, but the bulky group cannot compensate for the effect of noninterpenetration to the void volume. Therefore, the architecture in 2 has a larger void than in 1, up to 3380.5 Å3, that is, 45.2% of the cell volume. As for 3, the terminal group is the same as 2, but the space linker is longer than that of 1 and 2. The longer spacer would greatly decrease the influence of bulky group to interpenetration, and a interpenetrating α-Po network is observed in 3. Probably because the spacer has an obvious effect on interpenetration, which is enough to offset the negative effect from the bulky coordination sphere, the void volume is 4034.3 Å3, that is, 52.4% of the cell volume.

elements.content: Even with interpenetration, compound 3 still shows a large 1D channel consisting of double single-stranded helices. Fortunately, the trigonal channel is absent of solvent guests and counteranions, providing a rare “vacuum” porous material. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) were performed with fresh samples (), which suggest a guest-free channel in 3. The host framework decomposes at 358 °C, and this is a thermally stable framework.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Property

Even with interpenetration, compound 3 still shows a large 1D channel consisting of double single-stranded helices. Fortunately, the trigonal channel is absent of solvent guests and counteranions, providing a rare "vacuum" porous material. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) were performed with fresh samples (), which suggest a guest-free channel in 3. The host framework decomposes at 358 °C, and this is a thermally stable framework.

elements.content: As a thermal stable microporous MOF, the adsorption property of small gas molecule CO2 was measured for dry sample (Figure ). The adsorption isotherm exhibits an abrupt rise at low relative pressure (P/P 0), called a typical Type-I adsorption curve, which indicates the presence of uniform micropores in 3. The uptake amounts at 1.0 atm are 40 cm3 g−1 for CO2. Fitting the Langmuir equation to the isotherm gives an estimated surface area of ∼174 m2 g−1, and the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area is ∼148 m2 g−1. Notably, the monolayer coverage predicted by fitting the Langmuir and BET equations had a little difference, suggesting that there probably exist different numbers of accessible binding sites. Furthermore, the adsorption and desorption are reversible, which indicates that the incoming guest molecules can move freely into the channels, without forming H-bonding interactions with the pore surface.

elements.content: Three new coordination polymers 1−3 have been successfully synthesized by using three structurally related ligands, and their topological structures all represent α-Po MOFs based on homoleptic six-connected CdII nodes. Complexes 1 and 3 are double-interpenetrating networks, while 2 is a noninterpenetrating framework. The degree of interpenetration is tunable by varying ligand backbones; therefore, the porosity of these complexes was also adjusted. Besides illustrating an interpenetrating network, compound 3 is also a good example of porous material with high thermal stability and permanent porosity, which exhibits moderate gas adsorption for CO2.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three new coordination polymers 1-3 have been successfully synthesized by using three structurally related ligands, and their topological structures all represent α-Po MOFs based on homoleptic six-connected CdII nodes. Complexes 1 and 3 are double-interpenetrating networks, while 2 is a noninterpenetrating framework. The degree of interpenetration is tunable by varying ligand backbones; therefore, the porosity of these complexes was also adjusted. Besides illustrating an interpenetrating network, compound 3 is also a good example of porous material with high thermal stability and permanent porosity, which exhibits moderate gas adsorption for CO2.

elements.content: We employed the B3LYP method to calculate the volume of these coordination spheres. The 6-31g* basis set was used for C, H, N, and the Lanl2dz basis set associated with Ecps was employed for the CdII ion.
elements.clean_text:
References

We employed the B3LYP method to calculate the volume of these coordination spheres. The 6-31g* basis set was used for C, H, N, and the Lanl2dz basis set associated with Ecps was employed for the CdII ion.

A mixture of 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl (12.0 mmol, 3.74 g), benzoimidazole (60.0 mmol, 7.09 g), CuI (2.5 mmol, 0.47 g), 1,10-phenanthroline (6.0 mmol, 1.08 g), and K2CO3 (96.0 mmol, 13.27 g) was suspended in 120 mL of DMF. The mixture was refluxed for 6 days and then cooled to room temperature. Solvent was removed by distillation under a vacuum. CHCl3 (250 mL) was poured into the resulting brown sticky residue. The filtrate was washed with water (200 mL × 3), dried over anhydrous MgSO4, and then evaporated to obtain light-green mud. The crude product was separated by column chromatography (CH2Cl2/C2H5OHv/v = 18.5:1) to afford L 3 as light-yellow powder (yield: ∼20%, based on 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl). 300-MHz 1H NMR (δ, CDCl3): 8.20 (2H, s), 7.93 (2H, m), 7.87 (4H, d, 8.4), 7.68 (4H, d, 8.4), 7.64 (2H, m), 7.39 (2H, m). Anal. calcd for C26H18N4: C, 80.81; H, 4.69; N, 14.50. Found: C, 80.59; H, 4.57; N, 14.60%. IR (KBr, cm −1): 3424w, 3108w, 3075 m, 1901w, 1667w, 1607 m, 1508s, 1488s, 1454s, 1374w, 1288s, 1228s, 1204 m, 1138w, 1053w, 1005w, 888w, 827s, 807 m, 767 m, 750s, 714w, 577w, 523 m, 431w. MS (ESI): m/z = 387.5 for (HL 3 )+.

A buffer layer of CH3OH and CHCl3 (8 mL, 1:1) was carefully layered over a solution of L 1 (0.06 mmol, 12.6 mg) in CHCl3 (6 mL). Then a solution of Cd(BF4)2·6H2O (0.02 mmol, 7.9 mg) in CH3OH (6 mL) was layered over the buffer layer. Colorless block single crystals were obtained after several weeks. Yield: ∼30% (based on L 1 ). Calcd for C78H54CdCl2N12O8: C, 63.70; H, 3.78; N, 11.43. Found: C, 63.51; H, 3.90; N, 11.29%. cln_elements.content:
Compound 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c containing four symmetry-related CdII nodes in each unit cell. As shown in Figure a, the CdII ion lies in an octahedral coordination environment of six N-donors from independent L 2 ligands. These Cd−N bond lengths span a narrow range [2.368(3)−2.388(3) Å] in accord with the reported values. In the octahedral coordination geometry, the phenyl rings of benzoimidazole groups lie on the equatorial plane resulting in a loose arrangement, due to the cooperative effect of steric hindrance and π−π stacking. This array of terminal groups also steers the expanded direction of L 2 ligand, one-half upward, and downward for another (Figure a). The L 2 ligand bridges two adjacent CdII centers, and eight CdII nodes are connected by the ligands to form a cubic box with Cd···Cd separations of 13.032 and 13.973 Å (Figure b). A further extended structure illustrates a primitive cubic array without interpenetration. Significantly, the Cd···Cd edge of 13.973 Å is crisscross and spreads in two directions, which displays a distorted α-Po topology (Figure c). Because of its long dimensional edges, the cubic box shows much vacant space, and the overall void volume is about 3380.5 Å3, that is, 45.2% of the cell volume; however, the void space within this cationic framework {[Cd(L 2 )3]2+}∞, namely, the Mitsubishi channels, is occupied by ClO4 − counterions, chloroform and methanol molecules (Figure d).

As shown in Chart , in 1, the space linker is phenyl group, which could result in a moderate cavity in the targeted architecture. Taking the 334.6 cm3/mol coordination sphere into account, the α-Po network can accommodate another equivalent network to afford 2-fold interpenetration, which gives rise to 935.6 Å3 void after interpenetration, that is, 38.7% of the cell volume. For 2, although the space linker is the same as that of 1, the terminal group is much more bulky, and the volume of coordination sphere is up to 523.0 cm3/mol. The pronounced effect results in a noninterpenetrating network, but the bulky group cannot compensate for the effect of noninterpenetration to the void volume. Therefore, the architecture in 2 has a larger void than in 1, up to 3380.5 Å3, that is, 45.2% of the cell volume. As for 3, the terminal group is the same as 2, but the space linker is longer than that of 1 and 2. The longer spacer would greatly decrease the influence of bulky group to interpenetration, and a interpenetrating α-Po network is observed in 3. Probably because the spacer has an obvious effect on interpenetration, which is enough to offset the negative effect from the bulky coordination sphere, the void volume is 4034.3 Å3, that is, 52.4% of the cell volume.

Gas Adsorption Property

Even with interpenetration, compound 3 still shows a large 1D channel consisting of double single-stranded helices. Fortunately, the trigonal channel is absent of solvent guests and counteranions, providing a rare “vacuum” porous material. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) were performed with fresh samples (), which suggest a guest-free channel in 3. The host framework decomposes at 358 °C, and this is a thermally stable framework.

As a thermal stable microporous MOF, the adsorption property of small gas molecule CO2 was measured for dry sample (Figure ). The adsorption isotherm exhibits an abrupt rise at low relative pressure (P/P 0), called a typical Type-I adsorption curve, which indicates the presence of uniform micropores in 3. The uptake amounts at 1.0 atm are 40 cm3 g−1 for CO2. Fitting the Langmuir equation to the isotherm gives an estimated surface area of ∼174 m2 g−1, and the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area is ∼148 m2 g−1. Notably, the monolayer coverage predicted by fitting the Langmuir and BET equations had a little difference, suggesting that there probably exist different numbers of accessible binding sites. Furthermore, the adsorption and desorption are reversible, which indicates that the incoming guest molecules can move freely into the channels, without forming H-bonding interactions with the pore surface.
